text: Love this question. I hire in-house when the content I need requires some knowledge of our audience and subject matter. So I dont think you _need_ in-house for things like certain top of funnel work, some social work, some content repurposing, etc. Use freelance there. But the moment you need some tentpole content, new content series, interview/journalism style content or guides…. you need someone in house to help.

elements.text: Love this question. I hire in-house when the content I need requires some knowledge of our audience and subject matter. So I dont think you
need

text: I would add: Don't make any promises about using their quote. Always link back to their preferred site. Ask for profiles/headshots up front, too

text: How do you price out editing articles, not writing them?

elements.text: How do you price out editing articles, not writing them?

text: I don't do it often, but my friend who is an editor prices it out on a per word basis, billed in increments. E.g. .30 a word (not saying that should be your rate) billable in 500 word increments. Minimum project fee depends on your comfort level. My friend wouldn't touch anything worth lower than $100.

text:
Yep! What Jimmy said, and even some learnings since then.

Work backwards from the ideal amount of money you want to make from an hourly job (Let's say 150,000 / year)  

If you break that down to the hourly level, that turns out to be ~$72/ hour. 


This is important, because it informs everything that comes next, including how involved they're going to be. Asking the right questions is what will set you apart from others and justify higher rates.

For example, how much of research have they done for you vs how much will you have to do on your own? 

How much customer data do they already have vs how much will you have to find? 

Do they already have an advisory panel set up to review the work you _do_ submit, or are you going to have to wait a week or two while drafts change hands? Are you working with someone else internally on site copy? Do they have a brand book and/or style guide to make sure everything is on point? 

Your rate is ~$72 / hour. How many of those hours are they willing to pay for while they're getting their shit together?

text: This was helpful, thx. all. I do have an hourly goal, which was approved -- they wanted to get an idea, still, of how many hours. Reasonable, of course. But also clairvoyance! I'm also just reassured to know that even after so many years freelancing, I'm not the only one who, when asked how long it's going to take is all, I DUNNO! GIVE ME A DEADLINE AND A CAP!

text:
No negative impact on SEO, but consider this... There will be a subset of people who follow you across all mediums. 

If they ignore your caption/image on one platform, wouldn't it only compound the ignoring on the others? 

My take - (and I could be better at this) - tailor it to the channel. The audiences, use patterns, and environments are different enough that it's ripe for experimentation.

elements.text:
No negative impact on SEO, but consider this... There will be a subset of people who follow you across all mediums. 

If they ignore your caption/image on one platform, wouldn't it only compound the ignoring on the others? 

My take - (and I could be better at this) - tailor it to the channel. The audiences, use patterns, and environments are different enough that it's ripe for experimentation.

text:
In this exact position right now, going from a team of freelancers to hiring a FT inhouse content marketer. :slightly_smiling_face:

Agree with all of the above. Freelancers are a great help and will probably keep using them but at some point, I got caught up in an endless cycle of briefing, editing, uploading, promoting. I knew a second person was needed when I didn't have the time/energy to take on any new strategic projects without having to sacrifice the existing setup (which was growing nicely).

With a scope as broad as yours, it seems like you could definitely benefit from a second pair of hands (inhouse).

elements.text: In this exact position right now, going from a team of freelancers to hiring a FT inhouse content marketer.

text: You can own your audience more readily. If Medium goes out of business, you lose the entire audience you've built up. Plus, you can push people to sign up for an email list more easily on your own platform.

elements.text: You can own your audience more readily. If Medium goes out of business, you lose the entire audience you've built up. Plus, you can push people to sign up for an email list more easily on your own platform.
